title: 107_hr1973
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2001" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2001" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges gross misconduct, bias, serious conflict of interest, departure from procedural rules, or exceeding of powers by a panel, they can seek review in the Court of International Trade. If a party believes that actions have materially affected a binational panel decision and threaten its integrity, they can appeal to the United States Court of International Trade under the Tariff Act of 1930. The Court will review the panel's decision and vacate it if any misconduct is found. The United States Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. Decisions made by the Court are binding on the parties involved in the matter. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries that were subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. The United States Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. Decisions made by the Court are binding on the parties involved in the matter. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries that were subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. A competent investigating authority in the United States is responsible for duty determination. The United States Court of International Trade has jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. This section applies to goods from NAFTA countries subject to duty determinations in the United States. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA. This applies to duty determinations for goods from NAFTA countries in the United States Court of International Trade. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination by a binational panel under NAFTA for duty determinations on goods from NAFTA countries in the United States Court of International Trade. This includes a determination requested for review under section 404A of the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date. It also applies to goods from NAFTA countries as defined in the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.
